articles.headline: Gina Haspel, Trump’s Choice for C.I.A., Played Role in Torture Program
articles.snippet: Ms. Haspel, the deputy director of the C.I.A., ran a secret prison in Thailand in 2002 where a Qaeda suspect was waterboarded.
articles.abstract: Ms. Haspel, the deputy director of the C.I.A., ran a secret prison in Thailand in 2002 where a Qaeda suspect was waterboarded.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just over a year after the Sept. 11 attacks, the C.I.A. dispatched the veteran clandestine officer Gina Haspel to oversee a secret prison in Thailand. Shortly after, agency contractors in the frantic hunt for the conspirators waterboarded a Qaeda suspect three times and subjected him to brutal interrogation techniques.

articles.headline: Trump’s Killing of Chip Deal Pushes Protectionism as It Invokes Security
articles.snippet: President Trump’s sudden decision to halt Broadcom’s bid to take over Qualcomm reflects a concerted effort to protect American companies from China.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s sudden decision to halt Broadcom’s bid to take over Qualcomm reflects a concerted effort to protect American companies from China.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s swift decision this week to block a Singapore-based company from gaining control of Qualcomm grew out of a White House push to wall off American industry from foreign competition, primarily China, under the guise of protecting national security.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson, Cecilia Kang and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: In Replacing Tillerson With Pompeo, Trump Turns to Loyalists Who Reflect ‘America First’ Views
articles.snippet: Mr. Tillerson’s dismissal pulls the White House even further out of the economic and foreign policy mainstream and closer to the nationalist ideas that animated Mr. Trump’s presidential campaign.
articles.abstract: Mr. Tillerson’s dismissal pulls the White House even further out of the economic and foreign policy mainstream and closer to the nationalist ideas that animated Mr. Trump’s presidential campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump ousted on Tuesday his secretary of state, Rex W. Tillerson, the most dramatic in a cascade of personnel moves that suggest Mr. Trump is determined to surround himself with loyalists more willing to reflect his “America First” views.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Maggie Haberman and Gardiner Harris

articles.headline: No Result Yet in Pennsylvania House Race, but Democrat Declares Victory
articles.snippet: A special House election in western Pennsylvania ended the night too close to call, with Conor Lamb, a Democrat, and Rick Saccone, a Republican, separated by a few hundred votes.
articles.abstract: A special House election in western Pennsylvania ended the night too close to call, with Conor Lamb, a Democrat, and Rick Saccone, a Republican, separated by a few hundred votes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Update, March 14, 2018: The Democrat Conor Lamb has an insurmountable lead in a Pennsylvania House race in Trump country. We’re calling it in his favor.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Boeing May Become a Target in a Trade War Over Trump’s Tariffs
articles.snippet: As a massive manufacturing exporter, the aerospace giant is particularly vulnerable to retaliation from China, a major customer.
articles.abstract: As a massive manufacturing exporter, the aerospace giant is particularly vulnerable to retaliation from China, a major customer.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump will visit a Boeing plant in St. Louis on Wednesday to celebrate the tax cut his party handed to American companies. But lurking in the background is a clash over trade — one in which Boeing is the most vulnerable target.

articles.headline: At the Fox News Site, a Sudden Focus on Women as Sex Offenders
articles.snippet: After the harassment-related departures of executives and hosts, there was a spike in FoxNews.com articles on female teachers abusing students.
articles.abstract: After the harassment-related departures of executives and hosts, there was a spike in FoxNews.com articles on female teachers abusing students.
articles.lead_paragraph: In November, there was the story of a 22-year-old science teacher arrested in Oklahoma for her “sex romp” with a male student. In September, an article told of a 38-year-old teacher who kissed a student and let him “touch her breasts behind Culver’s,” a burger joint in Kerrville, Tex. And in July there was a report on a 54-year-old music teacher in Georgia who, a headline announced, “blames male student, 17, for tricking her into having sex ‘like a used-car salesman.’”

articles.headline: National School Walkout: Thousands Protest Against Gun Violence Across the U.S.
articles.snippet: In a coordinated action, students left their classrooms and sometimes marched in the streets a month after 17 people were killed in a Florida high school.
articles.abstract: In a coordinated action, students left their classrooms and sometimes marched in the streets a month after 17 people were killed in a Florida high school.
articles.lead_paragraph: A month ago, hundreds of teenagers ran for their lives from the hallways and classrooms of Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, where 17 students and staff had been shot to death.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: Walmart Expands Online Grocery Delivery to 100 Cities
articles.snippet: The retail giant is accelerating its efforts in the online-grocery sector as rivals, led by Amazon, wage their own aggressive campaigns for control of America’s kitchen cupboards.
articles.abstract: The retail giant is accelerating its efforts in the online-grocery sector as rivals, led by Amazon, wage their own aggressive campaigns for control of America’s kitchen cupboards.
articles.lead_paragraph: The path to fast and affordable online grocery service is littered with obstacles: refrigeration challenges, storage woes and high transportation costs, among others. But the country’s largest retailers are convinced that it will lead to a lucrative and largely untapped market.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: The Young and Brash of Tech Grow a Bit Older, and Wiser
articles.snippet: Former whiz kids who made their fortunes in the technology industry are now settling down, seemingly more attuned to the power they wield.
articles.abstract: Former whiz kids who made their fortunes in the technology industry are now settling down, seemingly more attuned to the power they wield.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several years ago, a plastic figurine began appearing around Google’s offices, an aging alien with gray hair, a Google Glass headset and a sign that read, “Get Off My Lawn!”
